title: How to Fold a Bandsaw Blade

steps.headline: Protect your skin and eyes while working with the saw blade.
steps.description: Cover as much of your skin as you can while you fold your saw blade. Wear long sleeves, pants, and thick gloves when you handle the saw blade so you don’t accidentally cut yourself. Wear safety glasses to keep the saw blade away from your eyes. Don’t handle the saw with your bare hands or else you may cut yourself.

steps.headline: Hold the blade with 2 hands so the teeth face you.
steps.description: Hold the saw out in front of you away from your body. Set the bottom of the blade on a level surface on the ground. Grab the blade one-third of the way down from the top on each side. Make sure your hands are on the outside of the saw. If you aren’t on a level surface, lay out a piece of wood underneath the saw blade.

steps.headline: Push the two sides of the blade together.
steps.description: Keep your arms out and away from your body. Bring your hands together slowly out in front of you until your thumbs touch. As you bring the blade together, the two sides will start to form a loop at the top. Make sure the blade doesn’t bend towards you while you’re bringing your hands together. If the blade starts to lean your way, tilt the blade forwards.

steps.headline: Take a step back so the top of the blade bends forward.
steps.description: Step away from the saw to start bending the top of the loop forward. Keep holding onto the blade as you slowly move backward so the blade doesn’t fall too quickly. Make sure the blade folds in half.

steps.headline: Cross your hands over one another to form loops in the blade.
steps.description: As the blade bends down, cross your left hand under your right hand to make the blade into a figure-8 pattern. The blade should now have a total of 3 loops. Lift the bottom loop with your left hand to coil the blade. Move slowly so you don’t lose control of the blade.

steps.headline: Hold the coiled bandsaw together with a wire tie.
steps.description: Wrap the wire around any part of the coiled blade so it’s tightly secure. If you want to secure it tighter, use a second wire tie on the opposite side of the coil. Store the blade in a dry place off of the ground. For a thinner blade, you can use small twist ties instead of larger wire ties.Tip: Keep the coiled blades in thick resealable bags and label their sizes with a marker. Keep them on a shelf or bench near your work area!

steps.headline: Undo the wire tie.
steps.description: Hold the coil in one hand as you undo the wire ties with the other. Keep the coil tight so you don’t lose control of it. Set the wire ties aside so you can easily find them the next time you need to coil the blade. Remember to wear thick work gloves so you don’t get cut by the saw teeth.

steps.headline: Find the loop that forms a figure-8 and pull it down.
steps.description: Hold the coil in one hand and use your other hand to pull the loops apart. When you find the figure-8 loop, let the bottom hang down while you hold the top 2 loops with your right hand. Keep the teeth pointed away from you while you uncoil the saw.

steps.headline: Grab each of the 2 crossing top loops.
steps.description: Twist the top coils slightly to make them form a cross. Take the top loop that’s crossing over the other in your right hand. Grab the other top loop with your left hand. Hold the blade out and away from your body so the hanging bottom piece doesn’t swing.

steps.headline: Rotate your hands down and outward to unfold the blade.
steps.description: Move your hands apart to pull the loops apart and unfold your blade completely. When you’re finished, your thumbs should be pointing up and the saw teeth should be pointing towards your body. Move slowly so the blade doesn’t slip or go out of control.

text: Coiling the Blade Protect your skin and eyes while working with the saw blade. Cover as much of your skin as you can while you fold your saw blade. Wear long sleeves, pants, and thick gloves when you handle the saw blade so you don’t accidentally cut yourself. Wear safety glasses to keep the saw blade away from your eyes. Don’t handle the saw with your bare hands or else you may cut yourself. Hold the blade with 2 hands so the teeth face you. Hold the saw out in front of you away from your body. Set the bottom of the blade on a level surface on the ground. Grab the blade one-third of the way down from the top on each side. Make sure your hands are on the outside of the saw. If you aren’t on a level surface, lay out a piece of wood underneath the saw blade. Push the two sides of the blade together. Keep your arms out and away from your body. Bring your hands together slowly out in front of you until your thumbs touch. As you bring the blade together, the two sides will start to form a loop at the top. Make sure the blade doesn’t bend towards you while you’re bringing your hands together. If the blade starts to lean your way, tilt the blade forwards. Take a step back so the top of the blade bends forward. Step away from the saw to start bending the top of the loop forward. Keep holding onto the blade as you slowly move backward so the blade doesn’t fall too quickly. Make sure the blade folds in half. Cross your hands over one another to form loops in the blade. As the blade bends down, cross your left hand under your right hand to make the blade into a figure-8 pattern. The blade should now have a total of 3 loops. Lift the bottom loop with your left hand to coil the blade. Move slowly so you don’t lose control of the blade. Hold the coiled bandsaw together with a wire tie. Wrap the wire around any part of the coiled blade so it’s tightly secure. If you want to secure it tighter, use a second wire tie on the opposite side of the coil. Store the blade in a dry place off of the ground. For a thinner blade, you can use small twist ties instead of larger wire ties.Tip: Keep the coiled blades in thick resealable bags and label their sizes with a marker. Keep them on a shelf or bench near your work area! Unfolding the Bandsaw Undo the wire tie. Hold the coil in one hand as you undo the wire ties with the other. Keep the coil tight so you don’t lose control of it. Set the wire ties aside so you can easily find them the next time you need to coil the blade. Remember to wear thick work gloves so you don’t get cut by the saw teeth. Find the loop that forms a figure-8 and pull it down. Hold the coil in one hand and use your other hand to pull the loops apart. When you find the figure-8 loop, let the bottom hang down while you hold the top 2 loops with your right hand. Keep the teeth pointed away from you while you uncoil the saw. Grab each of the 2 crossing top loops. Twist the top coils slightly to make them form a cross. Take the top loop that’s crossing over the other in your right hand. Grab the other top loop with your left hand. Hold the blade out and away from your body so the hanging bottom piece doesn’t swing. Rotate your hands down and outward to unfold the blade. Move your hands apart to pull the loops apart and unfold your blade completely. When you’re finished, your thumbs should be pointing up and the saw teeth should be pointing towards your body. Move slowly so the blade doesn’t slip or go out of control.

Cover as much of your skin as you can while you fold your saw blade.
Wear long sleeves, pants, and thick gloves when you handle the saw blade so you don’t accidentally cut yourself.
Wear safety glasses to keep the saw blade away from your eyes.
Don’t handle the saw with your bare hands or else you may cut yourself.
Hold the blade with 2 hands so the teeth face you.
Hold the saw out in front of you away from your body.
Set the bottom of the blade on a level surface on the ground.
Grab the blade one-third of the way down from the top on each side.
Make sure your hands are on the outside of the saw.
If you aren’t on a level surface, lay out a piece of wood underneath the saw blade.
Push the two sides of the blade together.
Keep your arms out and away from your body.
Bring your hands together slowly out in front of you until your thumbs touch.
As you bring the blade together, the two sides will start to form a loop at the top.
Make sure the blade doesn’t bend towards you while you’re bringing your hands together.
If the blade starts to lean your way, tilt the blade forwards.
Take a step back so the top of the blade bends forward.
Step away from the saw to start bending the top of the loop forward.
Keep holding onto the blade as you slowly move backward so the blade doesn’t fall too quickly.
Make sure the blade folds in half.
Cross your hands over one another to form loops in the blade.
As the blade bends down, cross your left hand under your right hand to make the blade into a figure-8 pattern.
The blade should now have a total of 3 loops.
Lift the bottom loop with your left hand to coil the blade.
Move slowly so you don’t lose control of the blade.
Hold the coiled bandsaw together with a wire tie.
Wrap the wire around any part of the coiled blade so it’s tightly secure.
If you want to secure it tighter, use a second wire tie on the opposite side of the coil.
Store the blade in a dry place off of the ground.
For a thinner blade, you can use small twist ties instead of larger wire ties.Tip: Keep the coiled blades in thick resealable bags and label their sizes with a marker.
Keep them on a shelf or bench near your work area!
Unfolding the Bandsaw Undo the wire tie.
Hold the coil in one hand as you undo the wire ties with the other.
Keep the coil tight so you don’t lose control of it.
Set the wire ties aside so you can easily find them the next time you need to coil the blade.
Remember to wear thick work gloves so you don’t get cut by the saw teeth.
Find the loop that forms a figure-8 and pull it down.
Hold the coil in one hand and use your other hand to pull the loops apart.
When you find the figure-8 loop, let the bottom hang down while you hold the top 2 loops with your right hand.
Keep the teeth pointed away from you while you uncoil the saw.
Grab each of the 2 crossing top loops.
Twist the top coils slightly to make them form a cross.
Take the top loop that’s crossing over the other in your right hand.
Grab the other top loop with your left hand.
Hold the blade out and away from your body so the hanging bottom piece doesn’t swing.
Rotate your hands down and outward to unfold the blade.
Move your hands apart to pull the loops apart and unfold your blade completely.
When you’re finished, your thumbs should be pointing up and the saw teeth should be pointing towards your body.
Move slowly so the blade doesn’t slip or go out of control.
